description: First used in 1908; borrowed from German Emmer, from Middle High German emeri, from Old High German amari, derivative of amar(o), which in turn gave rise to the obsolescent German synonym Amelkorn (“amelcorn”). Further etymology unknown.

entries.meaning: A species of wheat, Triticum dicoccon, one of a group of hulled wheats that are important food grains. [from 1908]
